item.title: Buying a Boat
item.content:encoded:
Buying a boat is a lot more complicated than buying a bike is. Soon, my bike will no longer be my most expensive vehicle (sorry bike. you've been outclassed).

  1. The first thing to do, even before shopping for a boat, is to qualify for a boat loan. This will give you extra leverage and make sellers take you seriously. Even if you're like me and you still get asked what grade you're in. There are a lot of loans available for boats that cost more than $25,000 and are newer than 30 years. Otherwise, your best bet will be to get a loan from a small local bank. Dress up professionally when visiting the bank and pretend that you've done this before.
  2. You now must make an offer and put a deposit down. This is where your boat surveyor comes in handy. She can tell you what the boat is worth, and a reasonable offer. It's probable that the seller knows what the boat is worth also, so don't embarrass yourself by offering something too much lower. If you decided not to buy the boat because it doesn't pass survey, your deposit should be refunded. You should always sign one of these: http://www.oceanmarinellc.com/brokerage/PurchaseandSaleAgreement.pdf

 

This is a useful link if you've been infected by the boat-buying bug: http://www.cyba.info/cybabuying.html

item.title: The Long and Winding Road to Being More Productive
item.content:encoded:
I wake up at 7am because I’m so excited about finishing the app that I had started writing the night before. I click the pomodoro timer in the upper left hand corner of Google Chrome to start the 25 minute count down. While it’s running, the pomodoro app blocks email, facebook and youtube. Ingenious, right? I love productivity apps.

Then I remember that productivity app with the binaural beats that I just got a free trial for...what was it called? I don’t remember, so I open my email. The timer is running so I can’t open gmail because it's blocked. No worries - I simply ‘switch person’ in chrome and open gmail there. I search for the activation notice in my email. Ah, it was called Focus@will.

I open it up and try to start the music. It doesn’t work. I try different browsers and different buttons for about five minutes before filing a support ticket.

Now that my other browser is open anyway, I decide to check facebook. Staring me in the face is an opinion piece on the New York Times about why women wear heals. Ok, I’ll take that bait. I read it. Then I see a link to an article in Fashion and Style, which reminds me that I haven’t read Modern Love in several weeks. Without even finishing the article about women in heels, I switch to Modern Love.

The timer rings, reminding me of why I’m working already at 7:30am. I just wasted an entire pomodoro doing things besides writing that app. Facepalm. 

I have trouble finishing things. 

Two years ago, I made a list of my unfinished projects. I hoped that seeing what I hadn’t finished would give me the kick in the pants that I needed to be more productive. The final list had over 100 projects on it. Rather than help me, reviewing this list discouraged me.

Why did I start projects at all if I wasn’t going to finish them? Why wake up early, miss out on sleep, give up relationships, and then fail to finish? And why start new projects while I still hadn't finished old ones? 

I stopped blogging, contributing to open source projects and creating new arduino projects. I also started dating someone who woke up early and went to bed early, so I changed my sleeping patterns and stopped doing all nighters and hanging out at makerspaces committing code and watching tutorials until 4am.

I stopped focusing on tech and I started focusing on people. I stopped attending tech meetups and hackathons, and I started organizing them. I made a lot of friends. I achieved more happiness, and I learned a lot about myself. But I still felt like something was missing. I missed the rush of having an idea and making it come to life on my own. I felt like a cheap hack for organizing events about making while I barely made anything myself.

The funny thing is that reading over the list of projects, I did eventually finish most of them. It just took me longer than my idealistic expectations could handle. Going through the list now, I realize that there are at least 10 more I could check off. I finished Shayne's Design Patterns book. I learned to play poker. I went through all of Lady Ada's tutorials.  

Almost every day I still have moments like the one I described at the beginning of this post. I wish that I didn't. I wish that I had better self-control and finished projects in four hours instead of four months. But I'm also no longer ashamed of taking four months to finish something. Maybe it's because I'm 26 and my chances of ever being a prodigy are now gone, so there's no hurry. 

Maybe it's because I finally feel like I've had some success with interpersonal relationships, and I realize that friendship is about being myself - not proving myself (I feel like there's another blog post in here somewhere). 

Or maybe, just maybe, it's because I've discovered an amazing new productivity app that I think will finally work to help me finish projects. Which is why next time I'm going to write about my experiences with the amazing app, HabitRPG.

item.title: The best things take time
item.content:encoded:
Not so long ago, I wrote an email about how I'm a terrible procrastinator and sent it to 30,000 people. 

Rereading it, I realized that the most important takeaway from writing that email is that things take time and I have to accept that.

Sure, Tim Ferris can learn a language in two weeks or whatever, but not everything can me hacked to make it go faster.  And even if it can be hacked, it's going to take you a few tries before you figure out the hack.

The other thing that is necessary to prevent procrastination is realizing that your personal projects are "worth it."
